To the Editor:
''The Pope's Act of Contrition'' (editorial, Sept. 20) is unfair to Pope Benedict XVI.
While the pope would never intentionally offend any world religion, he knows that true dialogue must be honest, and that is why his recent controversial remarks were not ''ill-considered comments.''
They were deliberate and were intended to recall the necessity of conjoining faith and reason: it is the uncoupling of these twin values that has delivered so much needless death in history.

Ironically, the Muslim response in many quarters has only underscored the veracity of the pope's remarks: a nun was shot to death in Somalia, apparently as a result; several churches were firebombed in the West Bank and Gaza; crowds in Kashmir and London have called for the death of the pope while burning him in effigy; a senior Turkish official compared the pope to Hitler; and an Internet posting by the Mujahedeen Shura Council has called upon Muslims ''to slit their throats,'' meaning Catholics'.
William A. Donohue President, Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights New York, Sept. 20, 2006
To the Editor:
Re your Sept. 20 editorial:
I, too, am offended, but not by the pope's remarks.
I am offended that Muslims went on a murderous rampage over a cartoon, but expressed no anger when a Dutch filmmaker was murdered in the name of Islam.
I am offended that moderate Muslims believed that an Afghan should be executed for converting to Christianity.
I am offended that many Muslims refuse to believe that Muslims perpetrated the 9/11 massacres.
Most of all, I am offended that when Islamic terrorists strike, Muslims offer no expressions of outrage.
At most, there is polite regret mixed with equivocations, rationalizations and qualifications from Muslim leaders and a deafening silence from the Muslim street.
Yet you would have us believe that the problem stems from the pope's absence from an interfaith conference.
Joseph Borini Las Vegas, Sept. 20, 2006
To the Editor:

In ''A Challenge, Not a Crusade'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 19), John L. Allen Jr., the Vatican correspondent for The National Catholic Reporter, says Pope Benedict XVI wants ''dialogue with teeth'' with Muslims.
While it is a rather aggressive image, I do think that we need to do more than chew over the same stale interfaith statements.
Interfaith partners also need to be aware of sometimes conflicting agendas that are relevant to how a disagreement is presented publicly.
Besides confusing religion with its many interpretations, some on both sides clearly seek division and to prevent certain developments, like Turkey's joining the European Union.
As a Muslim New Yorker active in interfaith dialogue, I have noticed a relative lack of grass-roots dialogue with the Catholic community.
This is especially problematic, since the decentralized structure of the Muslim community makes high-level, top-down dialogue difficult and often irrelevant to the wider community.
Instead of the tiresome round of global finger-pointing, let's involve local churches in sustained and financed relationship-building.
Let Catholics and Muslims challenge one another to embody real dialogue in action, serving the poor and disenfranchised.
It's time to get real.
Adem Carroll Astoria, Queens Sept. 19, 2006
The writer is board chairman of the Muslim Consultative Network.
To the Editor:
Media coverage of Pope Benedict XVI's speech has underreported two facts:
The Roman Catholic Church openly opposed the American-led war in Iraq, and the church has generally opposed the Israeli presence in the occupied territories.
Muslim leaders, take note:
On the two most inflammatory issues in the world today, the Catholic Church is on your side.
Horace Nalle Atlanta, Sept. 20, 2006
